PVC For Wires & Cables Introduction PVC Preparation Composition in PVC Compound Compound Density & Price Calculation Compound Density Calculation Compound Price Calculation Auto BOM Calculation Basic Formulation Troubleshooting Guides for Hold PVC Compounds About Me PVC RM Test Procedure PVC RM Specification History of PVC Introduction This is Bibhuranjan Bihari,Working as a Production Engineer in PVC Compounding in Anchor by Panasonic. I am a Plastic Engineer,graduated from CIPET,Bhubaneswar.I am an eager Android learner.Just Implemented some basic Ideas about PVC Compounding requried for Wires & Cable. If any Suggestion for the App improvement then Contact me on below mention ID.
History of PVC(Poly Vinyl Chloride) Polyvinyl chloride or PVC was first created by the German chemist Eugen Baumann in 1872.Vinyl is the second most produced plastic in the world. The first products from vinyl that Walter Semon produced were golf balls and shoe heels. Today, hundreds of products are made from vinyl, including: shower curtains, raincoats, wires, appliances, floor tiles, paints and surface coatings.PVC is a thermoplastic & Non hygroscopic material which is normally available in the rigid which no doubt can be brought in to flexible by adding suitable plasticizers.In PVC the chlorine content is 56.7% & however the value can be increased through chlorination process after which the product is well known for CPVC(Chlorinated Poly Vinyl Chloride)
Why PVC for Wires & Cables? PVC (Polyvinyl Chloride) â€“ is the most commonly used thermoplastic insulator for cables. It is cheap, durable and widely available. However, the chlorine in PVC (a halogen) causes the production of thick, toxic, black smoke when burnt and can be a health hazard The electrical characteristics of PVC such as electrical insulating properties or dielectric constant are excellent.To express electrical insulating properties, volume resistivity or dielectric strength is widely used as an index. The volume resistivity is expressed in terms of electrical resistance calculated per unit volume of the test piece. The dielectric strength is expressed in terms of the magnitude of voltage withstood without destruction of the test piece when a specified amount of voltage is applied for a specified period of time. In both cases, a higher value means better electrical characteristics. The volume resistivity of PVC products is slightly lower than those of olefin products, but since higher fire resistant properties are required for electrical components, PVC is used widely in a variety of applications such as electric cables for residential buildings, vehicles, household electrical appliances, cable coverings, insulating tapes, switch boxes, wire coverings, and protecting tubes for power and telecommunications cables. but since higher fire resistant properties are required for electrical components, PVC is used widely in a variety of applications such as electric cables for residential buildings, vehicles, household electrical appliances, cable coverings, insulating tapes, switch boxes, wire coverings, and protecting tubes for power and telecommunications cables. //////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// Raw Materials Name Raw Materials Density Phr
